U. S. ARMY WILL NEED OFFICERS
England's Experience Shows That College
Men Can Be Most Patriotic by Reserving Themselves for Positions
of Leadership, Says Dean.

In an interview with a representative of THE NEWS-LETTER,
Dean Murray P. Brush emphasized the idea brought forth in
the notice recently sent to every
Hopkins man by the President,
the Dean and Lieut. Elliott—the
idea that Hopkins students would
be serving their country more effectively by enlisting in the Reserve Officers' Training Corps
than by volunteering as privates.
"When the Government begins
the training of the enormous
armies which it is going to raise,"
said the dean, "it is going to
need officers, and need them badly.
It can obtain all the privates it
wants by conscription, but the material out of which officers can be
created is limited. College men,
by the training which they have
had, are peculiarly adapted for
this work, and they can turn their
patriotism to best account by preparing for it, rather than by succumbing to the very laudable desire of enlisting in the Government service immediately, as privates in the ranks."
One of the great mistakes which
England made in the early part of
the war, the dean went on to
show, was that it permitted the
majority of its university men to
enlist as privates when war was
first declared. Few of these men
survived the first few months of
combat, and; as a consequence,
England has had to face a serious
dearth of the men from whose
ranks its officers could be trained.
"The men here should understand," said the dean, "that by
remaining at the University and
drilling with the corps, they are
in no sense shirking their patriotic obligations. Indeed, it may
be said that they are showing
their patriotism in the wisest possible way. The great need of the
Government is not going to be for
privates, but for men to drill
those privates, and, for that purpose, enough officers will be
needed almost to form an army
in themselves."
The dean made clear that he
had nothing but praise for the
men who have already joined -the
United States forces. Tile promptness with which they have evidenced their love of country, he
said, does them the highest honor.
"In the case of the men who have
not yet decided just how they are
going to serve their country, however," he concluded, "I should
strongly advise careful consideration of what are going to be the
Government's most important
needs."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 16, 1917.
BATTALION HAS FIFTY RECRUITS

HOPKINS FELLOWS ANNOUNCED

New Company Is Formed --Daily Drills
Whipping Men into Shape—Corps to
Provide Officers for Training of U. S. Army.

Fifty-Two Graduate Scholarships and
Fellowships Awarded for 1917-18.
Bruce and Rayner Fellows
to Be Named Later.

With fifty recruits to swell its
ranks, with daily drills from 4 to
6 and half-day maneuvets on Saturdays, and with the definite
knowledge that its men will be
soon needed by the Government
to help in raising the enormous
new army for which the President has asked, the Hopkins Reserve Officers' Training Corps is
developing with unusual rapidity.
The letter sent to every undergraduate by President Goodnow,
Dean Brush and Lieut. Elliott,
urging every man who was physically fit to become a member of the
corps,found its response on Thursday afternoon, when over forty
new men lined up on the road in
front of the Civil Engineering
Building. Even before the letter
had been sent out, Lieut. Elliott
reported, two or three score of
men had made inquiries at his office in regard to joining the corps.
Friday brought another increase
to the ranks, and it is expected
that on Monday enough men will
have joined to permit of the official formation of another company. The addition of this company will bring the corps to full
battalion strength.
For the present, at least, Lieut.
Elliott has decided to abandon the
Wednesday, Thhrsday and Friday
lectures, and to devote the entire
time of the corps to drilling and
maneuvering. Lectures will be
given on days when for rain or
some other reason the regular
drill can not be held.
As soon as the recruits have'
been fully organized, Lieut. Elliott
hopes to make provision for their
uniforms and other equipment.
The great demand which has
arisen for equipment, for the
United States Army makes it impossible to secure uniforms for
the corps "from the'Mar Department. The lieutenant hopes, however, to obtain them from Fort
Howard, where there is known to
be a large supply.
With the intense training now
being provided, Lieut. Elliott is of
the opinion that many men from
the corps will be able to take the
examination for commissions as
second lieutenants in the reserve
by the end of the year. That such
officers will be needed, and needed
in great quantity, when once the
Government has set about raising
and training its new armies, there
can be no doubt. By preparing
themselveg to serve in this capacity, the lieutenant thinks,
Hopkins men are helping their
country in a very definite and
very real way.

Patriotism.

There are times when the
course of men becomes divested
of all the clogging, petty considerations of selfish expediency,
times when the elemental claims
of duty permit of no swerving
and no hesitation. There are times
when the individual becomes subordinate to the group, when the
sole question which each must
ask himself is how best he can
answer the call of his country.
The war upon which the United
States has embarked is a war
waged for the preservation of the
highest concepts of morality.
There is no tinselled lure of territory or renown, no glamor of
glory; there is nothing to be
gained save the thing greatest of
all-the recognition of a might
higher than the might of the
sword. The United States makes

Hopkins men will know no faltering in the hour of their country's need. That has been proved
already-proved by the list of

Ours can be no hectic, evanescent

that it must give, though the giving include life itself.
Yet, as men of a great university, our duty goes far beyond the
mere willingness to make sacrifice. It is not enough that we
act; we must think, and think
constantly, of the reasons for the
act. We must ever hold before
our eyes the redeeming fact that
the strife and hate into which the
world is plunged is not the end
in itself, but only the bloody prelude to an era in which the ideals
of democracy and justice shall

could have better served humanity by steadfastly refusing to

The Sensible Course.

To most Hopkins inen the question of what they should do in response to their country's call is
just now very acute. The lumbering uncertainty with which Congress is preparing to set about the
work of raising an army, the
present urgent call for volunteersand the patriotic thrill which is
in the air, all make the temptation to enlist under the colors immediately a temptation exceedingly strong. Nevertheless, both the
experience of other countries and
the advice of American authorities indicate that college men can
serve their country best by remaining where they are.
That the United States is going
to need officers very badly within
the next few years is a fact selfevident. It is equally clear that
the class of men who can be made
into officers is small, and that of
that class college men form a large
part. It was in recognition of
this condition that the Reserve
Officers' Training Corps were established at colleges throughout
the country. Now that provision
have been made at Hopkins for
daily drills of two hours, Hopkins
students can prepare themselves
to serve as officers within a comparatively short time.
. The most obvious objection to
joining the Corps, of course, is
that such action seems to be the
easiest way of fulfilling patriotic
obligations. Drilling in the Corps,
at present, means only the sacrifice of time, whereas enlistment in
some unit of the Army and Navy
is a course which entails much
greater sacrifice and, as a consequence, is more appealing. Nevertheless, occasions sometimes arise
when personal inclination, even
when it is prompted by the highest motives, should be subordinated to the general good. Joining the Corps instead of the regular service, after all, does not
mean that the sacrifices are
avoided--they are only deferred.
As Dean Brush has phrased it
elsewhere in this issue, for the
men who have already enlisted
there can only be the greatest and
most deeply felt respect. But
THE NEWS-LETTER joins with the
Dean in urging those men \‘'110 are
still undecided as to their course
of action, for the sake of the patriotism which is moving them,
to join the Corps.

FOUNDER OF INSTITUTE DIES

— AMUSEMENTS —

Dr. Janeway Makes Address at Annual
Dinner of Phi Beta Kappa Society.
Tells How War Has Helped
Science of Surgery.

"Diamond Jim" Brady Made Possible
One of University's Most Far-reaching
Works—Name Perpetuated in
Institute He Endowed.

President Goodnow Is Serving Upon
Three Separate Committees to Aid
Work of Preparing for War.
Favors Selective Draft.

FORD'S

Dr.Theodore Caldwell Janeway,
professor of medicine at the
Johns Hopkins University and
physician. in - chief to the Johns
Hopkins Hospital, delivered an
address upon "War and Medicine" at the annual dinner of the
Phi Beta Kappa Society, held at
the Emerson Hotel last Saturday
night.
Dr. Janeway, after he had been
introduced by Prof. Jacob H. Hollander, president of the Hopkins
chapter, began his address by
stating that the science of surgery owed much of its development to work done upon the battlefield. He went on to trace the
rise of the science from its earliest crude applications to the present day, s
The present war, Dr. Janeway
said, upset the calculations of
surgeons as much as it did the
calculations of those who said
that another great war was impossible. Before 1914, medicine
had been brought to the point
where it could easily prevent infection in the great majority of
wounds. In modern warfare, however, the range of artillery, and
the distance which wounded men
had to be removed from the front
before they could be adequately
treated, made it impossible to prevent infection, and, as a consequence, surgery had to• fight an
enemy which it had thought long
since vanquished. That lives could
now be saved without amputation
of the wounded members, even
after infection had set in, Dr.
Janeway said, was .one of the
greatest results medicine has ever
achieved.
Dr. Janeway paid tribute to the
work of the Medical Department
of the United States Army, which,
he said, had done such splendid
work in stamping out disease in
the Panama Canal Zone and in
the Philippines.
The present war, he said, in conclud lug his address was the first
war for several centuries in which
the flag of the Red Cross had not
been respected by a belligerent nation.

The news of the death of,"Diamond Jim" Brady, founder of the
Brady Urological Institute at the
Johns Hopkins Hospital, caused
deep sorrow throughout the University upon which his generosity
has been so greatly visited. That
generosity, it is said, has not
stopped even with death, for it is
rumored that Mr. Brady's will
contains a large bequest to be
used to maintain the institute
which he established.
Mr. Brady's closest friend in
Baltimore is Dr. Hugh Young,
who, in the millionaire's opinion,
saved his life when he came to
the Johns Hopkins Hospital in
1912. It was Dr. Young who
first broached the project of an
institute of urological surgery,
and who awakened Mr. Brady's
interest in the plan.
As soon as he decided to establish the institute, Mr. Brady commissioned Dr. Young to make a
thorough study of hospitals in
this country and in Europe, in
order to ascertain the best way
in which the institute could be
developed. On Dr. Young's return, plans fqr the building were
perfected, and the work of erection was begun immediately.
The dedication ceremonies of
the James Buchanan Brady Urological Institute—the second institution of its kind in the world
—were held in April, 1915. At
the banquet following the dedication, Mr. Brady made his famous
remark that, if millionaires could
appreciate how much better it
was to build memorials to themselves while they were alive, there
would be very few memorials
built to them after they were
dead.
The cost of establishing the institute amounted to $300,000, and,
throughout his life, Mr. Brady
was constantly providing for its
maintenance and for the extension of its work.

In the organization that Maryland is making in preparation for
the call to service, three calls have
been made upon President Frank
J. Goodnow.
When Maryland decided to take
a census of her men, Dr. Goodnow was made a member of the
committee appointed to take
charge of the work. This committee has set about organizing
a systematic inventory of Maryland's resources, and their work
is nearing completion.
Then came the call to Maryland
for 800 men for the Navy, and a
general organization was planned
for the carrying on of all forms
of recruiting. Dr. Goodnow was
asked to serve as chairman of the
organization.
Finally, when Baltimore saw
that war would cause hardship
to some or its population, and
when the committee for the relief of the poor was organized for
the purpose of raising $1,500,000,
Dr. Goodnow was again asked to
serve.
Dr. Goodnow has expressed
himself as unqualifiedly in favor
of the selective draft system now
under consideration in Congress.
"I certainly feel," he said recently, "that this is no time for
divided counsel and that the
Maryland delegation should give
President Wilson: the power he
asks. There is no doubt in my
mind that that is necessary if this
war is to be conducted vigorously.
"The selective draft is the only
sensible way in which to raise an
army, I think. Its merits do not
depend in any measure on whether
such an army, could be raised by
volunteer enlistment. I don't
think that should form any part
of the discussion at all. It is not
a volunteer army that is wanted.
What is wanted is the power to
select the men who are needed for
the army.
"H. G. Wells has said somewhere that there are only four
or five great nations that are capable of conducting a modern
war. War today is so much a
matter of industrial organization.
It would be absurd to cripple the
industrial organization of the
country and still further cripple
what little agricultural organization we have by'raising an army
by the -volunteer system. England found the absurdity of this
when she first went into the war."

"There are, it may be, many months of fiery trial and sacrifice ahead of
us. It is a fearful thing to lead this great peaceful pee pie into war; into the
most terrible and disastrous of all wars, civilization itself seeming to be in the
balance. But the right is more precious than peace and we shall fight for the
things which we have always carried nearest our hearts— for democracy, for
the right of those who submit to authority to have a voice in their own governments, for the rights and liberties of small nations, for a universal dominion
of right by such a concert of free peoples as shall bring peace and safety to
all nations and make the world itself at last free. To such a task we can
dedicate our lives and our fortunes, everything that we are and everything that
we have, with the pride of those who know that the day has come when
America is privileged to spend her blood and her might for the principles that
gave her birth and happiness and the peace which she has treasured. God
helping her, she can do no other."

DR. AMES ON WAY TO EUROPE
Heads Board Appointed by President
Wilson for Purposes of Scientific
Research --Dr. Reid Member of Commission.

Dr. Joseph S. Ames, professor
of physics, has been appointed by
President Wilson as'chairman of
a commission to investigate all
questions dealing with scientific
research in modern war problems,
and is already on his way to Europe. Dr. Harry Fielding Reid,
professor of dynamic geology and
geography, is another member of
the commission.
The commission was appointed
by the President upon the advice
of the National Research Council,
and forms one of the most concrete proofs that the United States
intends to co-ordinate with the
Allies to the fullest extent which
the Government has offered.
No definite information has been
furnished as to the exact nature
of the problems to which the commission will confine itself. That
the modern battlefield has many
such problems to offer—problems
which can be adequately investigated only by trained minds—has
been amply proved since August,
1914. Nor, it is thought, have
the resources of modern science
been brought to bear upon certain aspects of warfare as fully as
is possible. To ascertain all opportunities for the further introduction of the discoveries of the
laboratory into the methods of
armies, and, at the same time to
'bring other problems developed
by the war baCk to American laboratories to be investigated, is
the object of the commission.
Professor Ames is peculiarly
well fitted to head such a commission. Taking his A. B. degree at
this University in 1886, and his
Ph. D. in 1890, he has since been
made an honorary member of the
Royal Institution of Great Britain, a member of the French Physical Society, a member of the Na:
tional Academy of Sciences, fellow of the American Academy of
Arts and Sciences, assistant editor of the Astrophysical Journal

and associate editor of the American Journal of Science.
During the last year, Dr. Ames
has been actively engaged in the
work of the national Advisory
Committee on Aeronautics. Another fact which makes his selection as chairman or the commission a particularly appropriate
one is that he has made frequent
visits to France and England and
is in close relation with the leading scientists in both countries.
Dr. Reid, the other Hopkins
member of the commission, is also
a member of the National Academy of Sciences. It is said that
Dr. Reid, while in Europe, will
make a very thorough study of
photography from aeroplanes —
one of the most important works
in which the modern army en-.
gages. Dr. Reid brings to his
work experience as one of the leading seismologists of America.
Associated with Drs. Ames and
Reid on the commission are Dr.
Richard P. Strong, professor of
tropical medicine at Harvard University; Dr. Linsley R. Williams,
assistant health commissioner of
New York city; Dr. George A.
Hulett, professor of physical
chemistry at Princeton University, and Dr. George K. Burgess,
physicist at the Bureau of Standards, Washington.
The fact that two out of the six
members of the commission are
from Johns Hopkins University
is a very good indication of the
respect with which the Government regards Hopkins' scientific
attainments.

year's work, it is understood to be the sentiment among university
authorities that students can do most good by enlisting in the various
units already organized within the campus. Especial emphasis is

Officers' Training Corps already established by. the Government at
many universities, and it is expected that the reopening of the various
institutions after the Easter vacation will see the corps enormously
enlarged.

U. S. ARMY WILL NEED OFFICERS
England's Experience Shows That College
Men Can Be Most Patriotic by Reserving Themselves for Positions
of Leadership, Says Dean.

In an interview with a representative of THE NEWS-LETTER,
Dean Murray P. Brush emphasized the idea brought forth in
the notice recently sent to every
Hopkins man by the President,
the Dean and Lieut. Elliott—the
idea that Hopkins students would
be serving their country more effectively by enlisting in the Reserve Officers' Training Corps
than by volunteering as privates.
"When the Government begins
the training of the enormous
armies which it is going to raise,"
said the dean, "it is going to
need officers, and need them badly.
It can obtain all the privates it
wants by conscription, but the material out of which officers can be
created is limited. College men,
by the training which they have
had, are peculiarly adapted for
this work, and they can turn their
patriotism to best account by preparing for it, rather than by succumbing to the very laudable desire of enlisting in the Government service immediately, as privates in the ranks."
One of the great mistakes which
England made in the early part of
the war, the dean went on to
show, was that it permitted the
majority of its university men to
enlist as privates when war was
first declared. Few of these men
survived the first few months of
combat, and; as a consequence,
England has had to face a serious
dearth of the men from whose
ranks its officers could be trained.
"The men here should understand," said the dean, "that by
remaining at the University and
drilling with the corps, they are
in no sense shirking their patriotic obligations. Indeed, it may
be said that they are showing
their patriotism in the wisest possible way. The great need of the
Government is not going to be for
privates, but for men to drill
those privates, and, for that purpose, enough officers will be
needed almost to form an army
in themselves."
The dean made clear that he
had nothing but praise for the
men who have already joined -the
United States forces. Tile promptness with which they have evidenced their love of country, he
said, does them the highest honor.
"In the case of the men who have
not yet decided just how they are
going to serve their country, however," he concluded, "I should
strongly advise careful consideration of what are going to be the
Government's most important
needs."

BATTALION HAS FIFTY RECRUITS

HOPKINS FELLOWS ANNOUNCED

New Company Is Formed --Daily Drills
Whipping Men into Shape—Corps to
Provide Officers for Training of U. S. Army.

Fifty-Two Graduate Scholarships and
Fellowships Awarded for 1917-18.

to Be Named Later.

With fifty recruits to swell its
ranks, with daily drills from 4 to
6 and half-day maneuvets on Saturdays, and with the definite
knowledge that its men will be
soon needed by the Government
to help in raising the enormous
new army for which the President has asked, the Hopkins Reserve Officers' Training Corps is
developing with unusual rapidity.
The letter sent to every undergraduate by President Goodnow,
Dean Brush and Lieut. Elliott,
urging every man who was physically fit to become a member of the
corps,found its response on Thursday afternoon, when over forty
new men lined up on the road in
front of the Civil Engineering
Building. Even before the letter
had been sent out, Lieut. Elliott
reported, two or three score of
men had made inquiries at his office in regard to joining the corps.
Friday brought another increase
to the ranks, and it is expected
that on Monday enough men will
have joined to permit of the official formation of another company. The addition of this company will bring the corps to full
battalion strength.
For the present, at least, Lieut.
Elliott has decided to abandon the
Wednesday, Thhrsday and Friday
lectures, and to devote the entire
time of the corps to drilling and
maneuvering. Lectures will be
given on days when for rain or
some other reason the regular
drill can not be held.
As soon as the recruits have'
been fully organized, Lieut. Elliott
hopes to make provision for their
uniforms and other equipment.
The great demand which has
arisen for equipment, for the
United States Army makes it impossible to secure uniforms for
the corps "from the'Mar Department. The lieutenant hopes, however, to obtain them from Fort
Howard, where there is known to
be a large supply.
With the intense training now
being provided, Lieut. Elliott is of
the opinion that many men from
the corps will be able to take the
examination for commissions as
second lieutenants in the reserve
by the end of the year. That such
officers will be needed, and needed
in great quantity, when once the
Government has set about raising
and training its new armies, there
can be no doubt. By preparing
themselveg to serve in this capacity, the lieutenant thinks,
Hopkins men are helping their
country in a very definite and
very real way.

Patriotism.

There are times when the
course of men becomes divested
of all the clogging, petty considerations of selfish expediency,
times when the elemental claims
of duty permit of no swerving
and no hesitation. There are times
when the individual becomes subordinate to the group, when the
sole question which each must
ask himself is how best he can
answer the call of his country.
The war upon which the United
States has embarked is a war
waged for the preservation of the
highest concepts of morality.
There is no tinselled lure of territory or renown, no glamor of
glory; there is nothing to be
gained save the thing greatest of
all-the recognition of a might
higher than the might of the
sword. The United States makes
war not for itself, but for humanity.
Hopkins men will know no faltering in the hour of their country's need. That has been proved
already-proved by the list of
Hopkins names in the roster of

own fervor to the obligations

thinking men to underestimate

Ours can be no hectic, evanescent

first sacrifice must be met-it
must be loyalty which knows all
that it must give, though the giving include life itself.
Yet, as men of a great university, our duty goes far beyond the
mere willingness to make sacrifice. It is not enough that we
act; we must think, and think
constantly, of the reasons for the
act. We must ever hold before
our eyes the redeeming fact that
the strife and hate into which the
world is plunged is not the end
in itself, but only the bloody prelude to an era in which the ideals
of democracy and justice shall
reign in place of the ideals .of a

could have better served humanity by steadfastly refusing to
make war, under all provocations,

The Sensible Course.

To most Hopkins inen the question of what they should do in response to their country's call is
just now very acute. The lumbering uncertainty with which Congress is preparing to set about the
work of raising an army, the
present urgent call for volunteersand the patriotic thrill which is
in the air, all make the temptation to enlist under the colors immediately a temptation exceedingly strong. Nevertheless, both the
experience of other countries and
the advice of American authorities indicate that college men can
serve their country best by remaining where they are.
That the United States is going
to need officers very badly within
the next few years is a fact selfevident. It is equally clear that
the class of men who can be made
into officers is small, and that of
that class college men form a large
part. It was in recognition of
this condition that the Reserve
Officers' Training Corps were established at colleges throughout
the country. Now that provision
have been made at Hopkins for
daily drills of two hours, Hopkins
students can prepare themselves
to serve as officers within a comparatively short time.
. The most obvious objection to
joining the Corps, of course, is
that such action seems to be the
easiest way of fulfilling patriotic
obligations. Drilling in the Corps,
at present, means only the sacrifice of time, whereas enlistment in
some unit of the Army and Navy
is a course which entails much
greater sacrifice and, as a consequence, is more appealing. Nevertheless, occasions sometimes arise
when personal inclination, even
when it is prompted by the highest motives, should be subordinated to the general good. Joining the Corps instead of the regular service, after all, does not
mean that the sacrifices are
avoided--they are only deferred.
As Dean Brush has phrased it
elsewhere in this issue, for the
men who have already enlisted
there can only be the greatest and
most deeply felt respect. But
THE NEWS-LETTER joins with the
Dean in urging those men \‘'110 are
still undecided as to their course
of action, for the sake of the patriotism which is moving them,
to join the Corps.

FOUNDER OF INSTITUTE DIES

CALLED ON BY STATE AND CITY

— AMUSEMENTS —

Dr. Janeway Makes Address at Annual
Dinner of Phi Beta Kappa Society.
Tells How War Has Helped
Science of Surgery.

"Diamond Jim" Brady Made Possible
One of University's Most Far-reaching
Works—Name Perpetuated in
Institute He Endowed.

President Goodnow Is Serving Upon
Three Separate Committees to Aid
Work of Preparing for War.
Favors Selective Draft.

FORD'S

Dr.Theodore Caldwell Janeway,
professor of medicine at the
Johns Hopkins University and
physician. in - chief to the Johns
Hopkins Hospital, delivered an
address upon "War and Medicine" at the annual dinner of the
Phi Beta Kappa Society, held at
the Emerson Hotel last Saturday
night.
Dr. Janeway, after he had been
introduced by Prof. Jacob H. Hollander, president of the Hopkins
chapter, began his address by
stating that the science of surgery owed much of its development to work done upon the battlefield. He went on to trace the
rise of the science from its earliest crude applications to the present day, s
The present war, Dr. Janeway
said, upset the calculations of
surgeons as much as it did the
calculations of those who said
that another great war was impossible. Before 1914, medicine
had been brought to the point
where it could easily prevent infection in the great majority of
wounds. In modern warfare, however, the range of artillery, and
the distance which wounded men
had to be removed from the front
before they could be adequately
treated, made it impossible to prevent infection, and, as a consequence, surgery had to• fight an
enemy which it had thought long
since vanquished. That lives could
now be saved without amputation
of the wounded members, even
after infection had set in, Dr.
Janeway said, was .one of the
greatest results medicine has ever
achieved.
Dr. Janeway paid tribute to the
work of the Medical Department
of the United States Army, which,
he said, had done such splendid
work in stamping out disease in
the Panama Canal Zone and in
the Philippines.
The present war, he said, in conclud lug his address was the first
war for several centuries in which
the flag of the Red Cross had not
been respected by a belligerent nation.

The news of the death of,"Diamond Jim" Brady, founder of the
Brady Urological Institute at the
Johns Hopkins Hospital, caused
deep sorrow throughout the University upon which his generosity
has been so greatly visited. That
generosity, it is said, has not
stopped even with death, for it is
rumored that Mr. Brady's will
contains a large bequest to be
used to maintain the institute
which he established.
Mr. Brady's closest friend in
Baltimore is Dr. Hugh Young,
who, in the millionaire's opinion,
saved his life when he came to
the Johns Hopkins Hospital in
1912. It was Dr. Young who
first broached the project of an
institute of urological surgery,
and who awakened Mr. Brady's
interest in the plan.
As soon as he decided to establish the institute, Mr. Brady commissioned Dr. Young to make a
thorough study of hospitals in
this country and in Europe, in
order to ascertain the best way
in which the institute could be
developed. On Dr. Young's return, plans fqr the building were
perfected, and the work of erection was begun immediately.
The dedication ceremonies of
the James Buchanan Brady Urological Institute—the second institution of its kind in the world
—were held in April, 1915. At
the banquet following the dedication, Mr. Brady made his famous
remark that, if millionaires could
appreciate how much better it
was to build memorials to themselves while they were alive, there
would be very few memorials
built to them after they were
dead.
The cost of establishing the institute amounted to $300,000, and,
throughout his life, Mr. Brady
was constantly providing for its
maintenance and for the extension of its work.

In the organization that Maryland is making in preparation for
the call to service, three calls have
been made upon President Frank
J. Goodnow.
When Maryland decided to take
a census of her men, Dr. Goodnow was made a member of the
committee appointed to take
charge of the work. This committee has set about organizing
a systematic inventory of Maryland's resources, and their work
is nearing completion.
Then came the call to Maryland
for 800 men for the Navy, and a
general organization was planned
for the carrying on of all forms
of recruiting. Dr. Goodnow was
asked to serve as chairman of the
organization.
Finally, when Baltimore saw
that war would cause hardship
to some or its population, and
when the committee for the relief of the poor was organized for
the purpose of raising $1,500,000,
Dr. Goodnow was again asked to
serve.
Dr. Goodnow has expressed
himself as unqualifiedly in favor
of the selective draft system now
under consideration in Congress.
"I certainly feel," he said recently, "that this is no time for
divided counsel and that the
Maryland delegation should give
President Wilson: the power he
asks. There is no doubt in my
mind that that is necessary if this
war is to be conducted vigorously.
"The selective draft is the only
sensible way in which to raise an
army, I think. Its merits do not
depend in any measure on whether
such an army, could be raised by
volunteer enlistment. I don't
think that should form any part
of the discussion at all. It is not
a volunteer army that is wanted.
What is wanted is the power to
select the men who are needed for
the army.
"H. G. Wells has said somewhere that there are only four
or five great nations that are capable of conducting a modern
war. War today is so much a
matter of industrial organization.
It would be absurd to cripple the
industrial organization of the
country and still further cripple
what little agricultural organization we have by'raising an army
by the -volunteer system. England found the absurdity of this
when she first went into the war."

"There are, it may be, many months of fiery trial and sacrifice ahead of
us. It is a fearful thing to lead this great peaceful pee pie into war; into the
most terrible and disastrous of all wars, civilization itself seeming to be in the
balance. But the right is more precious than peace and we shall fight for the
things which we have always carried nearest our hearts— for democracy, for
the right of those who submit to authority to have a voice in their own governments, for the rights and liberties of small nations, for a universal dominion
of right by such a concert of free peoples as shall bring peace and safety to
all nations and make the world itself at last free. To such a task we can
dedicate our lives and our fortunes, everything that we are and everything that
we have, with the pride of those who know that the day has come when
America is privileged to spend her blood and her might for the principles that
gave her birth and happiness and the peace which she has treasured. God
helping her, she can do no other."

DR. AMES ON WAY TO EUROPE
Heads Board Appointed by President
Wilson for Purposes of Scientific
Research --Dr. Reid Member of Commission.

Dr. Joseph S. Ames, professor
of physics, has been appointed by
President Wilson as'chairman of
a commission to investigate all
questions dealing with scientific
research in modern war problems,
and is already on his way to Europe. Dr. Harry Fielding Reid,
professor of dynamic geology and
geography, is another member of
the commission.
The commission was appointed
by the President upon the advice
of the National Research Council,
and forms one of the most concrete proofs that the United States
intends to co-ordinate with the
Allies to the fullest extent which
the Government has offered.
No definite information has been
furnished as to the exact nature
of the problems to which the commission will confine itself. That
the modern battlefield has many
such problems to offer—problems
which can be adequately investigated only by trained minds—has
been amply proved since August,
1914. Nor, it is thought, have
the resources of modern science
been brought to bear upon certain aspects of warfare as fully as
is possible. To ascertain all opportunities for the further introduction of the discoveries of the
laboratory into the methods of
armies, and, at the same time to
'bring other problems developed
by the war baCk to American laboratories to be investigated, is
the object of the commission.
Professor Ames is peculiarly
well fitted to head such a commission. Taking his A. B. degree at
this University in 1886, and his
Ph. D. in 1890, he has since been
made an honorary member of the
Royal Institution of Great Britain, a member of the French Physical Society, a member of the Na:
tional Academy of Sciences, fellow of the American Academy of
Arts and Sciences, assistant editor of the Astrophysical Journal

and associate editor of the American Journal of Science.
During the last year, Dr. Ames
has been actively engaged in the
work of the national Advisory
Committee on Aeronautics. Another fact which makes his selection as chairman or the commission a particularly appropriate
one is that he has made frequent
visits to France and England and
is in close relation with the leading scientists in both countries.
Dr. Reid, the other Hopkins
member of the commission, is also
a member of the National Academy of Sciences. It is said that
Dr. Reid, while in Europe, will
make a very thorough study of
photography from aeroplanes —
one of the most important works
in which the modern army en-.
gages. Dr. Reid brings to his
work experience as one of the leading seismologists of America.
Associated with Drs. Ames and
Reid on the commission are Dr.
Richard P. Strong, professor of
tropical medicine at Harvard University; Dr. Linsley R. Williams,
assistant health commissioner of
New York city; Dr. George A.
Hulett, professor of physical
chemistry at Princeton University, and Dr. George K. Burgess,
physicist at the Bureau of Standards, Washington.
The fact that two out of the six
members of the commission are
from Johns Hopkins University
is a very good indication of the
respect with which the Government regards Hopkins' scientific
attainments.

many universities, and it is expected that the reopening of the various
